body:
To be clear, are you suggesting implementing Futures like functionality for
the local scheduler?  I think that this would be a requirement.  I think
that it might require implementing an entirely new local scheduler.

No objections from me, but you might find that this is a moderately large
undertaking.

On Wed, Jul 8, 2020, 5:18 PM jakirkham <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Currently with Distributed we have Futures
> <https://distributed.dask.org/en/latest/api.html#future> in that context.
> However there doesn't exist a first class Future object within Dask
> itself. It would be useful to have a first class Future object within
> Dask. This would enable a wider set of algorithms and provided some needed
> flexibility for various problems people run into today.
>
> First having a Future object would be useful in cases where we want to
> submit some work to start and then construct later operations with the
> knowledge that these results will soon become available (one example might
> be writing these to disk). Second this can be a useful way to prioritize
> elements of a workflow where we know what we want to prioritize (like
> working with large chunks of memory first). Third can help in cases where
> we want to interleave work between subtasks (recentering, normalizing,
> binning, etc.). Fourth this can be useful when the results of tasks are
> needed to more informatively generate new work (working with unknown
> chunks, selection based on data values, etc.). Fifth this can be a useful
> way of cutting down on large task graph handling issues (this is something
> other distributed libraries use #3514 (comment)
> <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/3514#issuecomment-390502785> ).
> There may be more ways this functionality could be used, but hopefully this
> provides some ideas on where/how it might help.
>
> Additionally have gone through the issue tracker and identified
> issues/cases where this would either solve or help solve the underlying
> problem. This is not necessarily comprehensive. Also some issues may
> require more work on top of this. However in all cases this seems to
> provide a meaningful base to build on. Here's the list:
>
>    - #874 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/874>
>    - #1519 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/1519>
>    - #2156 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/2156> (at least
>    practically)
>    - #3074 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/3074> (useful for)
>    - #3255 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/3255> (useful for)
>    - #3514 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/3514>
>    - #3587 (comment)
>    <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/3587#issuecomment-396729211>
>    - #3595 (comment)
>    <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/3595#issuecomment-396971956>
>    - #4156 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/4156> (useful for)
>    - #4149 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/4149> (useful for)
>    - #4544 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/4544>
>
> Note this likely (though happy to be proven wrong) depends on moving to
> concurrent.futures as documented in issue ( #6220
> <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/6220> ).
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/6380>, or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AACKZTF74VDJ4BVTGJYOGALR2UEGNANCNFSM4OVCGQOQ>
> .
>

Yeah that's right. I agree. It does require some thought on what the local scheduler would look like. Am hoping this will be a bit easier with things like `concurrent.futures` ( https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/6220 ), but I could be wrong about that.

I understand. If you have suggestions on how we should approach this, would be open to them 🙂

My only suggestion is to make sure that it's worth your time before going
in.  Things will get complicated.

On Wed, Jul 8, 2020 at 6:52 PM jakirkham <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Yeah that's right. I agree. It does require some thought on what the local
> scheduler would look like. Am hoping this will be a bit easier with things
> like concurrent.futures ( #6220 <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/6220>
> ), but I could be wrong about that.
>
> I understand. If you have suggestions on how we should approach this,
> would be open to them 🙂
